thread.title: Tex. victim of Australia plane crash was afraid of small aircraft
thread.title_full: Tex. victim of Australia plane crash was afraid of small aircraft

author: RICH SCHAPIRO
title: Tex. victim of Australia plane crash was afraid of small aircraft
text:
Texas man killed in Australia plane crash with his golfing buddies had just voiced his fear of small aircraft Tex. victim of Australia plane crash was afraid of small aircraft NEW YORK DAILY NEWS   4:45 PM 
One of the four Texas golfing buddies killed in a plane crash in Australia had days earlier expressed his fear of traveling in a small aircraft. 
Glenn Garland, the former CEO of an Austin-based energy consulting firm, posted on Facebook a photo of his wife Laurie standing in front of a puddle jumper in New Zealand. 
“How can she be so calm when I’m worried about needing an extra pair of underwear,” Garland wrote on Feb. 8. 
“I only burned 5,000 calories of anxiety on the flight over,” Garland wrote after the scenic flight. “I’m not so much on those smaller planes even though we had a great pilot.” 
Garland and his three friends — Russell Munsch, Greg DeHaven and John Washburn — died Tuesday morning when their twin-propeller plane crashed into a mall shortly after taking off from a Melbourne airport. 
Aussie pilot Max Quartermain, who reported “catastrophic engine failure” moments before the crash, was also killed. The twin-propeller plane crashed into a mall Tuesday morning shortly after taking off from a Melbourne airport. (AP) 
Investigators were probing the cause of the accident. 
The four pals were heading to King Island, just north of Tasmania, two weeks into their “once in a lifetime” golf tour of the region, relatives said. 
Small plane crashes on street in Bayonne, N.J. 
The victims’ wives joined them on the three-week trip but reportedly skipped the doomed flight to tour the scenic Great Ocean Road along Australian’s southern coast. 
“Glenn Garland was more than a colleague to me, he was a visionary and a close friend,” said Jim Stimmel, the co-founder of Garland’s old firm, CLEAResult. “I am devastated to hear of his passing and my heart and thoughts are with his family. We have all lost an incredible man.” 
Munsch had recently retired from the law firm he co-founded 40 years ago. Glenn Garland was one of the victims of a plane crash in Melbourne, Australia. (Facebook) 
“Russ was enjoying retirement, and doing what he loved almost more than practicing law — playing golf,” the Munsch Hardt firm said in a statement. “Russ was a lawyer’s lawyer, one of the best of all time.” 
Washburn was a former executive at Sammons Enterprises, a global holding company based in Dallas. 
DeHaven, 70, was a retired FBI agent with three children and six grandchildren. 
“He was a great guy, a man’s man,” his sister, Denelle Wicht told the Daily News late Monday. Tags:
